James C. Scott

James Scott is a political scientist and anthropologist, most famous for his work on the limitations of state rationality, peasant economy and the "subaltern" political activity of groups excluded by the state. His work highlights the intimate connection between the Weberian-Westphalian state and impersonal enlightenment rationality. On his score, states can govern only through the schema of such a rationality and their activities are legitimated in turn by the prestige of it. I argue that implicit within Scott's anthropological and social-scientific work is an antinomian or "anarchist" critique of the state grounded in an epistemic critique of impersonal enlightenment reason. For Scott, effective practical reasoning needs to be contextually-sensitive and is unavoidably perspectival â€“ reasons belong to an agent in virtue of the time and place in which they are situated. The "synoptic" rationality of the large-scale state, which can govern only on the basis of an impersonal standpoint disembedded from time and place, is revealed to suffer from stark limitations in his work.
